coredata.dc:title: Defect-rich bimetallic UiO-66(Hf-Zr): Solvent-free rapid synthesis and robust ambient-temperature oxidative desulfurization performance
coredata.dc:creator: Ye, Gan
Wang, Hanlu
Zeng, Xingye
Wang, Lei
Wang, Jin
coredata.dc:description: Desulfurization of fuel oil is an indispensable step to obtain clean energy source. Design of bimetallic metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with plentiful defects and highly dispersion active species, opens a new door to boost the catalytic activity for targeted reactions. In this work, we demonstrate a rapid green approach for fabricating bimetallic UiO-66(Hf-Zr) with highly dispersion of Hf/Zr-OH defect sites under solvent-free condition. UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) exhibited superior activity for oxidating sulfur compounds (1000 ppm S) of fuel oil at room temperature within 15 min. The turnover frequency (TOF) number reach 129.5 h-1 at 30 °C, which is 32.2 times higher than pristine UiO-66(Zr). Theoretical results reveal that the exposed Hf-OH sites readily react with H2O2 to produce Hf-OOH intermediates which manipulate the reaction performance. Our work not only proposes a green solvent-free avenue for rapid preparation of defective bimetallic MOFs but also extends the application of bimetallic MOFs in the field of desulfurization.

Defect sites
Solvent-free
Oxidation desulfurization
Room temperature

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (a) Schematic illustration of the synthetic process of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr), (b) XRD patterns, (c) N2 sorption isotherms and the pore size distribution curves (inset) of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) and UiO-66(Zr), (d) SEM image, (e) TEM image, (f) HR-TEM image and (g) elemental mapping images of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr).
(a) TGA curves, (b) FT-IR spectra, (c) Raman spectroscopy and (d) UV–vis spectra of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) and UiO-66(Zr).
XPS spectra of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) and UiO-66(Zr): (a) Hf 4f, (b) Zr 3d, (c) O 1s and (d) C 1s.
Potentiometric acid-base titration curve and first derivative curve for (a) UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) and (b) UiO-66(Zr).

(a) Catalytic activities of various catalysts, influence of different (b) acetonitrile dosage, (c) the O/S molar ratio, and (d) sulfur content on catalytic activities of UiO-66(0.13Hf/Zr). Reaction conditions: 50 mg catalyst, 10 mL model fuel, 5 mL acetonitrile (a, c and d), H2O2 as oxidant, O/S molar ratio of 4 (a, b and d), 1000 ppm sulfur of DBT (a, b and c), 30 oC.

Effect of (a) reaction temperature, (b) sulfur substrate, and (c) reusability on catalytic activities of UiO-66(0.13Hf/Zr), (d) TOF number of different samples. Reaction conditions: 50 mg catalyst, 10 mL model fuel, 5 mL acetonitrile, H2O2 as oxidant, O/S molar ratio of 4, 1000 ppm sulfur, and 30 °C (b and c).

(a) Leaching and quenching experiments over UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) in the ODS reaction of DBT. Reaction conditions: catalyst (50 mg), model oil (10 mL), acetonitrile (5 mL), sulfur of DBT (1000 ppm), oxidant (H2O2), O/S molar ratio (4:1), 30 °C, p-benzoquinone (2 mmol) or tertiary butanol (4 mmol).
Optimized geometries and relative free energies of various samples at M06L/6-31G (d, p) (C, O, H), LANL2DZ (Zr, Hf) level.
Proposed ODS reaction mechanism of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr).
Comparison of catalytic activities over several representative MOFs and MOFs-based catalysts in the ODS reaction of DBT.

ce:table-footnote.ce:note-para: TOF = (mole number of converted sulfur) / (mole of active species in catalyst × reaction time (h)),

head.ce:title: Defect-rich bimetallic UiO-66(Hf-Zr): Solvent-free rapid synthesis and robust ambient-temperature oxidative desulfurization performance

ce:footnote.ce:note-para: These authors contributed equally: Gan Ye, Hanlu Wang

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Desulfurization of fuel oil is an indispensable step to obtain clean energy source. Design of bimetallic metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with plentiful defects and highly dispersion active species, opens a new door to boost the catalytic activity for targeted reactions. In this work, we demonstrate a rapid green approach for fabricating bimetallic UiO-66(Hf-Zr) with highly dispersion of Hf/Zr-OH defect sites under solvent-free condition. UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) exhibited superior activity for oxidating sulfur compounds (1000 ppm S) of fuel oil at room temperature within 15 min. The turnover frequency (TOF) number reach 129.5 h-1 at 30 °C, which is 32.2 times higher than pristine UiO-66(Zr). Theoretical results reveal that the exposed Hf-OH sites readily react with H2O2 to produce Hf-OOH intermediates which manipulate the reaction performance. Our work not only proposes a green solvent-free avenue for rapid preparation of defective bimetallic MOFs but also extends the application of bimetallic MOFs in the field of desulfurization.

ce:section.ce:para: Deep desulfurization as a crucial method to produce clean energy source should be promising way for solving the increasingly environmental issue [1,2]. The industrial hydrodesulfurization (HDS) own to its limitation is hard to eliminate refractory sulfur compounds like 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT) [3,4]. Oxidative desulfurization (ODS) with superior ability to oxidate refractory aromatic sulfur compounds under mild condition becomes one of great promising processes to obtain clean fuel oil [5–8]. Until now, kinds of materials based on metal oxide [2,9], metal cluster [10], polyoxometalates [6,11], ionic liquid [12,13] or Ti-containing zeolite [14,15] have been used as ODS catalyst to dig their capability for producing ultra-low sulfur content fuel oil. However, most of them still needed tedious process for preparing catalyst, high reaction temperature, long reaction time or organic oxidant to obtain the considerable desulfurization efficiency, or can only remove single sulfur compound [15–17]. Therefore, the synthesis of omnipotent ODS catalysts for eliminating sulfur at ambient temperature has been of great interest.

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with remarkable stability, tunable porosity, large surface area have become excellent candidates for extensive applications [18–23]. For this, several MOFs have been considered as supports for encapsulating active species to remove sulfur compounds of model oil in ODS reaction [2,24–26]. Unfortunately, most reactants with relatively big size are difficult to access the active sites because of the narrow pores of MOFs, which result in the ordinary catalytic activity even at high reaction temperature [27–29]. Pristine MOFs inherently with coordination unsaturated sites exhibited remarkable catalytic activity [30–32]. However, the preparation of MOFs with rich defects is still a challenging task, which imposes restriction on catalytic activity [15,33–37]. Bimetallic MOFs with plentiful defect sites not only can introduce more active metal atoms but also magnify the synergistic effect, which can break the bottleneck [38–40]. Therefore, the economic and environmental way for synthesizing defective bimetallic MOFs should be a promising avenue to boost the catalytic performance of MOFs. As far as we know, no work on the use of solvent-free method for synthesizing Zr and Hf based bimetallic MOFs and employment of them as ODS catalysts has been reported.

In this work, we presented a rapid green approach to prepare Hf and Zr based defective bimetallic UiO-66(Hf-Zr) by solvent-free route. The obtained UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) displayed extraordinarily ODS performance to eliminate dibenzothiophene (DBT) or 4,6-DMDBT (1000 ppm S) within 15 min at room temperature. Additionally, UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) also presented great potential application in acetalization and the oxidation of styrene and benzyl alcohol at room temperature. The theoretical and experimental studies demonstrated that the exposed Hf-OH sites readily react with oxidant to form Hf-OOH intermediate, which can efficiently remove sulfur compounds.

Zirconium oxychloride octahydrate (ZrOCl2∙8H2O), hafnium dichloride oxide octahydrate (HfOCl2∙8H2O), hafnium tetrachloride (HfCl4), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC), benzothiophene (BT), dibenzothiophene (DBT), 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT), benzyl alcohol, styrene, benzaldehyde, NaNO3, NaOH, p-benzoquinone and ethanol were purchased from Beijing InnoChem Science & Technology Co., Ltd. N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF), formic acid, methanol, acetonitrile, n-octane, hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 30 wt%), concentrated sulfuric acid (H2SO4), hydrochloric acid (HCl, 37%) and tertiary butanol were purchased from Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. The real diesel sample was obtained from Maoming petrochemical company. All chemicals were analytically pure and used without further purification.

Solvent-free synthesis of UiO-66(Hf-Zr): 1.8, 1.6, 1.4 or 1.2 mmol ZrOCl2∙8H2O, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6 or 0.8 mmol HfOCl2∙8H2O, and 2 mmol BDC were mixed in a mortar and ground by hand for 7 min under ambient condition. The obtained mixtures were transferred into 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and crystallized at 130 °C for different time. After naturally cooled to room temperature, the resulting solids were separately washed with 20 mL ethanol, 50 mL ethanol at 70 °C for 6 h, and 20 mL ethanol. After that, the obtained samples were dried at 150 °C for 12 h. The final product was denoted as X% UiO-66(Hf-Zr)-X h (where X% and X h represent the molar percentage of introduced HfOCl2∙8H2O and crystallization time during the synthesis respectively).

Solvent-free synthesis of UiO-66(Zr): 2 mmol ZrOCl2∙8H2O and 2 mmol BDC were mixed in a mortar and ground by hand for 7 min under ambient condition. The obtained mixture was transferred into 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and crystallized at 130 °C for 3 h. After naturally cooled to room temperature, the resulting solid was separately washed with 20 mL ethanol, 50 mL ethanol at 70 °C for 6 h, and 20 mL ethanol. After that, the obtained sample was dried at 150 °C for 12 h.

Solvothermal synthesis of UiO-66(Hf)-solvent: HfCl4 (240 mg) and BDC (124 mg) were added into a solution containing 18 mL DMF and 2 mL formic acid. After stirred 30 min, the mixture was transferred to a 40 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and placed in an oven at 120 °C for 48 h. After naturally cooled to room temperature, the resulting solid was separately washed twice with 20 mL DMF and with 50 mL ethanol at 70 °C for 6 h. After that, the obtained sample was dried at 150 °C for 12 h.

Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-2550 diffractometer equipped with a SolX detector-Cu Ka radiation with wavelength of λ = 1.5418 Å. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were recorded on SUPRA 55 operated with an acceleration voltage of 15 kV. Nitrogen sorption isotherms were obtained at 77 K on a BSD-PS1 Gas Sorption and Porosimetry system (The samples were normally degassed at 423 K under vacuum until a final pressure of 1 × 10-3 Torr was reached prior to the measurement). Transmission electron microscope (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images were acquired with a FEI Tecnai G2 F30 operated at 300 kV with an energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrometer. Raman spectra was collected with a Renishaw in Via Raman microscope with a He/Ne laser excitation at 532 nm (2.33 eV). Fourier Transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra was recorded on a NicoLET iS10 spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out on TGA Q500. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on an Axis ultra DLD (Kratos analytical) with a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source (hν = 1486.6 eV). UV–visible absorption spectra was recorded on a UV-2500 scanning spectrophotometer (Shimadzu). Hf and Zr contents were determined with an iCAP 7600 ICP-OES analyzer calibrated with standard solutions. Potentiometric acid-base titrations were conducted with a Metrohm Titrando 905 autotitrator equipped with Dosino 800 20 mL and 10 mL dosing units.

1000 ppm S of DBT or 4,6-DMDBT was dissolved in n-octane to act as model fuel. Typically, a mixed solution of 10 mL model fuel and 5 mL acetonitrile (extraction phase) was sealed with 50 mg catalyst (activated at 150 °C for 12 h) in a 30 mL dram vial. The suspension was then vigorously stirred (600 rpm) in water bath at 30 °C for 10 min to ensure extractive balance. The reaction process was initiated by the addition of oxidant (H2O2, 30 wt%) with an H2O2/sulfur (O/S) molar ratio of 4. The agitation of reaction solution was stopped at regular intervals until the liquids layered (about 5 s). The liquid in n-octane (upper layer) was withdrawn and analyzed by GC (Agilent 8860 chromatograph, HP-5 column, FID detector) and GC-MS (Agilent 7890B chromatograph, HP-5 MS column, 5977B MSD detector). The removal rate (R) of sulfur was calculated based on the equation: R = (1-C t /C 0 ) × 100% (C 0 and C t stand for the initial concentration and after-t-minute-reaction concentration of sulfur in n-octane phase).

The reusability of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) was tested on ODS of DBT and 4,6-DMDBT at 30 °C. After each run, the catalyst was recovered by centrifugation, followed by washing with fresh CH3CN twice and drying at 150 °C for 12 h, and reused in the next ODS cycle under the same reaction condition.

The geometry optimizations performed with M06L. The effective core potential (ECP) LANL2DZ was used for the transition metal zirconium and hafnium atoms and their corresponding basis sets, while a basis set of 6–31G (d, p) was used for the rest atoms, such as H, O and C atoms. UiO-66(Zr) with perfect crystal structure (defect-free) has six Zr atoms occupying each vertex of the regular octahedron, and 12 BDC linkers on each Zr6 node to form a three-dimensional MOF. To save computational time, BDC was replaced by formic acid (HCOO) for UiO-66(Zr) framework and four of the surfaces were hydroxylated (μ3-OH), resulting in a molecular formula of Zr6(HCOO)12(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4. All of the above calculations were accomplished by the Gaussian16 software package.

Fig. 1(a) illustrates the solvent-free approach for preparing UiO-66(Hf-Zr) approach. The obtained samples were investigated by XRD, N2 sorption and ODS reaction of DBT. The crystallization temperature was fixed at 130 °C with the introduction of 20% HfOCl2∙8H2O (molar percentage). It was found that the crystallization of UiO-66(Hf-Zr) could be completed within a short time of 2 h (Fig. S1a). Obviously, the samples obtained at 3 h possessed good crystallinity and appropriate BET surface area (849 m2/g, Fig. S1b, Table S1). The influence of different molar percentage of HfOCl2∙8H2O on the crystal structure was then studied at a fixed crystallization time of 3 h. The well-crystalline UiO-66(Hf-Zr) (Fig. S2a) structure can be formed until introduction of 40% HfOCl2∙8H2O. The BET surface areas gradually decrease with the increased Hf content (Fig. S2b, Table S1 and S2). The catalytic activities of as-synthesized samples for ODS reaction of DBT were assessed at 30 °C. The removal of sulfur over 20% UiO-66(Hf-Zr)−3 h reached 99.8% within 15 min, which is far superior to other samples (Fig. S3a and b). The 20% UiO-66(Hf-Zr)−3 h sample, named as UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) (the molar ratio of Hf and Zr is 0.13: 1) as the representative sample for further detailed characterization and study.

As shown in Fig. 1(b), the powder XRD pattern of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) closely resembles that of synthesized UiO-66(Zr) and the simulated pattern of UiO-66, demonstrating that the UiO-66 structure is well retained in UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr). The loading of Hf in UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) is 0.7 per Zr-oxo cluster based on ICP-OES results (Table S1). The N2 adsorption isotherm of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) exhibits a jump with hysteresis loop at P/P
0 = 0.9, similar to UiO-66(Zr), which can be due to N2 condensation in the void volume between small particles (Fig. 1c and inset). The BET surface area of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) reaches 849 m2/g, which is slightly lower than that of UiO-66(Zr) (923 m2/g) due to the introduction of larger Hf atom. The SEM and TEM images of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) display a morphology of sheet shape with inhomogeneous particle size (Fig. 1d and e), similar to that of UiO-66(Zr) synthesized via the solvent-free approach (Fig. S4). No lattice spacing could be observed in the HR-TEM image of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) (Fig. 1f), owing to the rapid destruction of the crystalline structure of UiO-66 under illumination of high-intensity electron beam. The element mappings of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) confirm that the Hf, Zr, O and C elements are homogeneously distributed throughout the sample (Fig. 1g).

The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) confirms that UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) possesses a weight loss curve similar to that of UiO-66(Zr) and very good thermal stability until 500 °C ( Fig. 2a). The last weight loss of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) is smaller than that of UiO-66(Zr), which can be attributed to the formation of HfO2. The FT-IR spectrum of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) is quite similar to that of UiO-66(Zr), indicating that they possess same coordination modes (Fig. 2b and S5) [41]. To further investigate the structure, Raman spectroscopy was applied (Fig. 2c). Compared with UiO-66(Zr), a new band at 195 cm-1 emerged in UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr), which can be assigned to the stretching mode of the Hf-O bond [42]. The main UV–vis absorption bands of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) exhibit a blue shift relative to UiO-66(Zr) (Fig. 2d), indicating a single ligand-to-metal charge transfer between organic ligand and Hf-Zr nodes.

To validate the chemical composition and bonds in UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr), XPS analysis was performed with UiO-66(Zr) as a reference sample. The XPS survey spectrum of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) verified the presence of Hf, Zr, O and C elements, in agreement with the element mapping results (Fig. S6). As shown in Fig. 3(a), the two peaks at around 17.1 and 18.8 eV correspond to Hf 4f7/2 and Hf 4f5/2, and can be assigned to the Hf4+ oxidation state [42,43]. The XPS spectra of Zr 3d show that Zr in UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) and UiO-66(Zr) can both be assigned to 4 + oxidation state (Fig. 3b) [44,45]. In UiO-66(Zr), three O 1s peaks centered at 530.1, 531.8 and 533.3 eV can be assigned to the Zr–O–Zr, Zr–O–C and COO bonds respectively [44]. Comparably, the O 1s binding energy of Zr-O-Zr/Hf in UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) is slightly reduced to 529.7 eV, with part of Zr atoms replaced by Hf atoms (Fig. 3c). The peak corresponding to the COO bond belong to BDC slightly increases to 533.7 eV, further indicating the presence of charge transfer between organic ligand and Hf atom in UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr), and the same phenomenon can be found in the XPS spectra of C 1s (Fig. 3d), in which the peak referring to CC bond increases to 286.4 eV [6,28].

Potentiometric acid-base titration has been confirmed to be an accurate approach to quantify the number of defects in MOFs [41,46,47]. UiO-66(Zr) with the ideal crystal (defect-free) has 12 BDC linkers on the secondary building units (SBUs), and only one type of proton (μ 3-OH) can be titrated on the ZrO4(OH)4 cluster. Once defects are formed, two new protons (Zr-OH2 and Zr-OH) that cap the defect sites can also be titrated. Other titratable protons are hardly introduced under the solvent-free synthetic condition. Thus, only three types of protons are present. Each type of proton has a distinct pK a value, and can be identified and quantified. The titration curve and its first derivative for UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) are shown in Fig. 4(a), with those of UiO-66(Zr) shown in parallel for better visualization of the different equivalence points (Fig. 4b). There are three distinct equivalence points corresponding to three types of protons (μ 3-OH, Zr-OH2 and Zr-OH). The first equivalence point can be assigned to the proton on μ 3-OH. The second and the third ones are the protons on Zr-OH2 and Zr-OH, respectively. Based on the calculation results (Table S3), the number of missing linkers is 1.8 per SBU, or equivalently, 3.6 out of 12 linkers associated with each Zr-oxo cluster in an ideal UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr). Comparably, 3.44 missing linkers per Zr-oxo cluster are present in UiO-66(Zr) (Table S4) and 2.74 missing linkers (including coordination formic acid) on the Hf-oxo cluster are present in UiO-66(Hf)-solvent (Fig. S7 and Table S5). The potentiometric acid-base titration further shows that most of the defect sites in UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) is occupied by Zr-OH or Hf-OH (90%, Table S3) that is highly active in many catalytic reactions [41,47].

The catalytic performance on ODS reactions was evaluated at 30 °C in a water bath to avoid the influence of the local temperature. Fig. 5(a) presented the sulfur removal efficiency of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr), UiO-66(Zr) and UiO-66(Hf)-solvent. Obviously, UiO-66(Hf)-solvent synthesized under solvothermal method showed no catalytic activity on ODS reaction. The removal of sulfur about 40% could be ascribed to the extraction process. UiO-66(Zr) exhibited inactive catalytic performance, with only 77.9% sulfur removed after a reaction time of 30 min. It was worth noting that about 40% DBT was extracted into acetonitrile phase. GC-MS results further revealed that a total of 50.6% sulfur was oxidized in both phases with UiO-66(Zr) as the catalyst (Fig. S8). Notably, the removal of sulfur over UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) reached 99.8% after a reaction time of 15 min. The number of missing linkers in UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) is 3.6 per Zr-oxo cluster, which similar to that of in UiO-66(Zr) (3.44). Obviously, the catalytic performance of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) is superior to UiO-66(Zr), confirming that Hf site is more active than Zr site. As for UiO-66(Hf)-solvent, all the defect sites were occupied by Hf sites, however it has fewer defect sites than UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) resulting no catalytic activity in ODS reaction. The results indicated that more defect sites in MOFs can improve their catalytic performance. Moreover, only 0.3% DBT could be detected in the extraction phase by GC-MS after reaction, confirming that a total amount of 99.5% DBT has been oxidized (Fig. S8). The adsorption capacity of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) for removing sulfur of DBT is below 3.5%. The result confirmed that the adsorption has little effect in ODS reaction (Fig. S9). Fig. 5(b) presented the effect of different acetonitrile dosage on catalytic performance of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr). The sulfur removal efficiency reached 99.1%, 99.8%, 99.6% and 99.3% at reaction time of 20, 15, 20 and 20 min when 2.5 mL, 5 mL, 7.5 mL and 10 mL acetonitrile was used as the extraction phase respectively. The different acetonitrile phase after reaction was detected by GC-MS, and confirmed that almost no DBT remained in acetonitrile phase (except 2.5 mL, Fig. S10). The results indicate that a small amount of extractant can meet considerable ODS activity. The influence of O/S molar ratio on the catalytic activity was shown in Fig. 5(c). The reaction activity of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) increased with O/S molar ratio from 2 to 4, then decreased slightly upon further increasing the O/S molar ratio. The result could be attributed that the excessive oxidant was spitted to oxygen by catalyst, which was easily adsorbed on the surface of catalyst to prevent active sites contact with reactant. The sulfur removal efficiency could reach 98.2% after a reaction time of 30 min when the O/S molar ratio is 2. The result can be due to that part of H2O2 is broken down into O2 by the catalyst, as small bubbles were formed when H2O2 was added in the reaction system. When the O/S molar ratio is 3, the sulfur removal efficiency could reach 99.3% within 20 min. A sulfur removal efficiency of 99.8% could be achieved within 15 min with an optimal O/S molar ratio of 4. The result demonstrated that UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) can offer high ODS efficiency with exceptionally diluted oxidant. As the sulfur content increased from 500 ppm to 2000 ppm, only slightly longer reaction time (within 40 min) was needed for the complete removal of DBT (Fig. 5d).

Reaction temperature plays an important role on the catalytic performance. As shown in Fig. 6(a), the ODS activity increases with reaction temperature. The sulfur can be completely removed within 4 min at 50 °C. According to the temperature-dependent results, the reaction rate constants (k) and activation energy (Ea) were calculated based on the first-order kinetic law: ln (C0/Ct) = -kt and ln k = -Ea/RT (where C0 and Ct represent the concentration of sulfur at the initial and t time, Fig. S11 and Table S6) and an Ea value of 64.6 kJ/mol was derived (Table S7). In addition, the refractory 4,6-DMDBT, which is hard to eliminate by hydrodesulfurization, could also be completely removed after 15 min at 30 °C. BT was the most difficult to oxidize using ODS process, and displayed 70.8% removal after 30 min at 30 °C (Fig. 6b).

A model diesel oil was prepared with 20% BT, 40% DBT and 40% 4,6-DMDBT in n-octane (1000 ppm S) to evaluate the catalytic activity of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr). As shown in Fig. S12, the removal of sulfur could reach 94.4% within 60 min at 30 °C. The result indicated that 1000 ppm sulfur in model diesel can be reduced to 56 ppm. Moreover, the real diesel sample with sulfur content of 3580 ppm was obtained from Maoming petrochemical company. Composition analysis showed that the real diesel sample contained unsaturated hydrocarbons and other impurities. The total sulfur in real diesel was determined by using EDX-7000 spectrometer. Before testing the sulfur content in real diesel was diluted to 1193 ppm by fresh n-octane. The removal sulfur of real diesel reached 48.1% at 30 °C and 64.9% at 50 °C under the same reaction condition with model diesel. The test result indicated that about 14% sulfur was extracted into acetonitrile phase, even that the removal sulfur efficient in real diesel was lower than that of model diesel. The results can be ascribed that the unsaturated hydrocarbons are competitively oxidized with sulfur and the active sites were easily blocked by impurities in real diesel.

The reusability of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) was tested by the ODS reaction of DBT and 4,6-DMDBT at 30 °C. As shown in Fig. 6(c) and Fig. S13, almost no appreciable degradation on the removal efficiency could be noticed within the first three cycles. After 3rh cycle, longer reaction time was needed to obtain considerable catalytic efficiency. The results could be ascribed that the small amount of catalyst lost during each cycle. XRD and N2 absorption techniques were used to assess the structural stability of reused catalyst, and confirmed that the structure of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) was retained after recycle (Fig. S14 and S15).

To have a comprehensive view of the outstanding ODS activity of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr), the performance of several representative MOFs and MOFs-based catalysts for ODS reaction of DBT were summarized in Table 1. Most MOFs-based catalysts required reaction temperature above 50 °C to reach considerable ODS activity, and their TOF values were below 30 h-1 [48,49]. W/UiO-66(Zr)−0.12 [50], Ti-BDC-A [15], HP-UiO-66(Zr) [17] and MOF-808(Zr) [36] exhibited good catalytic activity at low temperature, but their TOF values were obviously lower than that of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr). Notably, the TOF number of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) could reach 129.5 h-1 at 30 °C, which is 32.2 times higher than pristine UiO-66(Zr) (Fig. 6d). The TOF number could rise up to 487.7 h-1 at 50 oC (calculation based on the exposed of Hf atoms), outperforming most of the reported ODS catalysts.

Leaching and quenching experiments were conducted to probe the possible reaction mechanism. Tertiary butanol (TBA) or p-benzoquinone (BQ) was usually used as the scavengers for hydroxyl radicals (HO • ) or superoxide radicals (O2 •−), respectively [15,36]. As shown in Fig. 7, the ODS activity was almost completely inhibited when UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) was removed from the reaction system at a reaction time of 5 min, indicating that no leaching has occurred. When TBA or BQ was added into the reaction system, the ODS performance was almost not affected. The results indicated that HO • and O2 •− play an inessential role. A weak inhibition could be observed when both TBA and BQ were added, which can be attributed to occupation of partial active sites by excessive BQ and TBA (the molar ratio of BQ or TBA to H2O2 was 2.2: 1 or 4.4: 1). The results confirmed that HO • and O2 •− radicals play an inessential role in the ODS reaction. According to previous literature reports, some transition metals can readily react with H2O2 to form superoxide species (M-OOH) might act as the active species [24,27,50], which will be further studied as follows.

To better understand the role of the introduction of Hf sites in UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) and catalytic reaction mechanism, Theoretical calculations were performed. The structures of UiO-66(Zr) and UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) were optimized on M06L level (Fig. S16). The molecular formula of UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) was considered to be Zr5Hf(HCOO)12(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4 and named as Hf/UiO-66(5Zr), as approximately one Zr atom per Zr-oxo cluster was replaced by Hf atom. Dissociation of one HCOO- group leads to two vacancies which will be occupied by -OH and -OH2 respectively. The structure was denoted as Hf-OH/UiO-66(5Zr) for the case of formation of Hf-OH and Zr-OH-Hf/UiO-66(5Zr) for the case of formation of Zr-OH. According to the calculation results, the Gibbs free energy (G) of Hf-OH/UiO-66(5Zr) was calculated to be 36.5 kJ mol-1 lower than that of Zr-OH-Hf/UiO-66(5Zr), indicating that -OH is thermodynamically easier to coordinate with Hf to form Hf-OH. As discussed previously, superoxide species (M-OOH), which can be formed by reaction M (Zr or Hf)-OH-Hf/UiO-66(5Zr) with H2O2, might play a critical role in the ODS activity. If formed Hf-OOH or Zr-OOH, the structures named as Hf-OOH/UiO-66(5Zr) or Zr-OOH-Hf/UiO-66(5Zr). The G of formation of Hf-OOH (the resulting structure was denoted as Hf-OOH/UiO-66(5Zr)) was calculated to be 19.7 kJ mol-1 lower than that of formation of Zr-OOH (the resulting structure was denoted as Zr-OOH-Hf/UiO-66(5Zr)), demonstrated that Hf-OOH is indeed more easily formed in thermodynamics ( Fig. 8).

According to experimental and theoretical results, a possible ODS reaction mechanism was described in Scheme 1. After extractive balance about 40% sulfur compound in model oil could be extracted into acetonitrile phase and adsorbed inside or on the surface of the catalyst. When H2O2 was added into the reaction system, it also penetrated into acetonitrile phase. Hf-OH in UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) easily reacted with H2O2 to form Hf-superoxide species (Hf-OOH). Then, the adsorbed sulfur compound could be oxidized into sulfoxide by one Hf-OOH, and further oxidized into sulphone by the other Hf-OOH, as confirmed by GC-MS (Fig. S17 and Scheme S1).

In addition, UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) also exhibited excellent catalytic performance in acidic catalytic reaction (acetalization of benzaldehyde by methanol) and other catalytic oxidation reaction (the oxidation of benzyl alcohol and styrene). The conversion of 6 mmol benzaldehyde over UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) could reach 92% after a reaction time of 2 min at room temperature (Scheme S2). The conversion of benzyl alcohol (1 mmol, Scheme S3) and styrene (1 mmol, Scheme S4) reached 10.6% and 11.9% with a selectivity of 100% for benzaldehyde and 90% for styrene oxide at room temperature for 24 h, respectively. UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) with plentiful defect sites (2.4% based on Hf sites) not only acts as Lewis acid catalyst benefitting acidic catalytic reaction (acetalization), but also possesses rich Hf-OH sites that readily react with oxidant to form Hf-superoxide species highly efficient for oxidation reaction. The results indicated that UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) has great potential applications in various catalytic reactions.

In summary, we exploited a green and rapid approach to prepare bimetallic UiO-66(Hf-Zr) with rich defect sites under the solvent-free condition. The characterization results demonstrated that 0.7 Zr atom were replaced by Hf atom per Zr-oxo cluster, and formed Zr-Hf-oxo cluster with considerable Zr/Hf-OH active sites. UiO-66(0.13Hf-Zr) with the suitable number of Hf sites and defects exhibited remarkable ODS activity for the removal of DBT and 4,6-DMDBT, achieving a complete removal of 1000 ppm sulfur within 15 min at 30 °C. The TOF value (487.7 h-1) at 50 °C is the higher than most of the reported ODS catalysts. Theoretical and experimental study confirmed that the introduction of Hf sites plays a vital role to react with H2O2 to form Hf-OOH intermediates and determines catalytic rate. Our work presented a rapid solvent-free approach to prepare bimetallic UiO-66(Hf-Zr) with the high-efficiency desulfurization of fuel oil at mild conditions, and indicated that the bimetallic MOFs can be used for various applications.

Gan Ye: Research, Experimental conducting, Writing – original draft, Funding acquisition. Hanlu Wang and Xingye Zeng: Theoretical calculations. Lei Wang: Discussion. Jin Wang: Funding acquisition, Revision, Supervision.
